instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
hey there, I am not the greatest with USBC boards, and this issue in particular drives me nuts everytime.
Currently i have 2 boards showing this exact symptom:
when charger is connected i get 5.17V (steady) on both ports, and 0Amps draw.
PPBUS is missing (0V) and not shorted to ground, no shorted highside cpu mosfets.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is fine (3.34v) and reaches the pads under the CD3215s
I get all LDO voltages on the CD3215s, except I don't get the <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> rail.

So far on both boards i have tried reworking and replacing the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and the USB redriver chip next to the ports as well as the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> (the latter more out of desperation)
Also replaced the CD3215s multiple times (always in pairs, and these boards need the C00 chips, so that's what i've used)

Is a missing PP1V1 LDO caused by a bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, and am i just being extremely unlucky and keep putting bad CD3215s on the board?
There is only one cap on this LDO rail and that cap is fine (i.e. not shorted or no fucked pads)

Am i missing something? I haven't posted a lot of measurements, i know, but i'm off work now till after the weekend, so can get back with more measurements.

Thanks in advance!

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
"replacing the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>"
I hope you've soldered one from exact same board model.
That is USB ROM chip; it has firmware!

Check diode mode to ground at 1V1 LDO output and compare with similar board.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
I used a <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 (whereas my board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A), will that make a difference?

Diode mode to ground on 1v1 LDO is 0.453 on both CD3215s on the bad board.
on a known-good one (also a 00840-A) it is 0.448, so this seems fine, right?

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Doesn't look low.
But is LDO output and should appear with 5V at USB-C input I think.
Do a search on the forum and check if is possible to confirm that on other posts.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
yeah I think that's true. I have checked a working board and the 1v1 LDO (along with all other Vouts of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>) comes on immediately after connecting charger, while it is still in the 5v mode.
Geezzz does that mean I should try another set of CD3215s? or is there something else left to check first?

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
1V1 LDO output was missing on both chips in first stage?
Did you try the 4 way connections possible for USB-C charger?

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
yes, it's missing on both CD3215s. 
In the meantime, i have replaced both of them again on one of the boards, but still getting no 1v1 out.. 
And, yes i have tried all 4 orientations of the connector.

All other LDOs are working at the proper voltages on each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message: Try removing redriver chip...

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Just tried it without the redriver. 
no change. still taking 5.17v at 0amps on all four connector orientations.
I'm waiting on a new batch of CD3215s and some donorboards that are coming in next week, but this is the third set of CD3215s I've put on, can't imagine I have so much bad luck on two boards simultaneously

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
You MUST get all LDO voltages from <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; with just 5V on corresponding USB-C port.
I've just got the confirmation from 00239 board.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Yes, that's what I confirmed on the working 00840-board yesterday as well.
So for now, the conclusion is that the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is bad? or is there any condition required before this LDO is created? I can't figure it out from the schematics really..

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Check each fuse close to <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
Post voltage for (free) pads of <CAPACITOR>C3120</CAPACITOR>/21 and <CAPACITOR>C3220</CAPACITOR>/21.
Don't make short there, or you can fry <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>...

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
OK, finally had time to get back to this one, loads of other junk to get out of the way first..

F3000/3010 Fuses are checked and ok.

When charger connected to port A:
<CAPACITOR>C3120</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.20V /  pad 2: 7.49V
<CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.19V /  pad 2: 10.97V

Charger connected to port B:
<CAPACITOR>C3220</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.20V / pad 2: 7.26V
<CAPACITOR>C3221</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.19V / pad 2: 10.94V

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
So <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200 are correctly controlled.

You must get all LDO voltages.
If no short on any, shpuld be <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue...

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Jesus I have another couple of these with only missing LDO being the 1v1 BMC one.
I have a hunch that this is a sign of bad CD3215s. 
Need to find better sellers. Anyone have any good sources for the C00 version (apart from Louis obviously)

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message: Hello captainmac, I also have this symptomps, any progress/ update? I have replaced a total of 6 chip, doesnt looks like a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> failure to me

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
no update yet. the only constant is that I'm using preballed CD3215s from Ali. I have run out of donors  and my orders are taking too long.
What kind of chips are you using?

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Im using donor cd3215coo in the form of chicken wings like rossmann, bought it from ali too...
In my case, i don't have 20v on dc in, but if i put battery, it can turn on and boot normally, only cannot charge.., maybe you can check if it does turn on with charged battery?

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message: yeah, mine arent turning on on battery only.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Hi guys,
I was just checking if you made any progress with this issue ?
I happen to have a board with the exact same issue. One of the CD3215s gives me no 1V1. I have replaced it 3 times now, with chips I purchased reballed from different vendors on Ali. I also replaced the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on that side of the board, just in case.
The LDO output is not shorted to ground on the PCB (measured while <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> was removed).
I had a look at the datasheet for <CHIP>TPS65986</CHIP> (closest chip to the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>), but nothing in there really telling the criteria for that LDO to turn on during the chip power-up sequence :(

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
If this helps to anyone, I had one with all LDO present in both CD3215C. I first replace <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, same result. I try everything and i test everything and I couldn't find anything wrong, so I replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> because I have nothing else to do and I got the 20V back and 0.49 amps.

Originally was 5V 0.2 amps.

threads.title: 00840 5volts on both ports
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback.
We still need to gather more information about USB-C boards...
